questions.text: EBV is associated with all of the following, except: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. MALT lymphoma

 

Explanation:

 

Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is not associated with MALT (Mucosa-Associated Lymphoid Tissue) lymphoma. EBV has well-established links to several specific malignancies, but MALT lymphoma is not among them. MALT lymphoma is primarily associated with chronic antigenic stimulation, particularly Helicobacter pylori infection in gastric MALT lymphomas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma - This statement is correct. EBV has a strong and well-documented association with nasopharyngeal carcinoma, particularly in persons of Chinese origin. This relationship is one of the classic examples of viral oncogenesis.

 

Option B. Hodgkin's lymphoma - This statement is correct. EBV is implicated in the pathogenesis of Hodgkin's lymphoma, especially the mixed-cellularity type. The virus can be detected in Reed-Sternberg cells, which are the hallmark cells of Hodgkin's lymphoma.

 

Option C. Infectious mononucleosis - This statement is correct. Infectious mononucleosis, also known as the "kissing disease," is the classic clinical manifestation of primary EBV infection. It presents with fever, exudative pharyngitis, cervical lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, and atypical lymphocytosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

EBV plays a significant role in various lymphoproliferative disorders and epithelial cancers including Burkitt's lymphoma, Hodgkin's lymphoma, nasopharyngeal carcinoma, and infectious mononucleosis, but has no established role in the pathogenesis of MALT lymphoma.

questions.text: What components constitute the backbone of a DNA molecule?(NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Alternating phosphate and sugar groups

 

Explanation:

 

The DNA molecule has a backbone made up of alternating deoxyribose sugar and phosphate groups connected by 3',5'-phosphodiester bonds. This structure creates the "backbone" of DNA, while the nitrogenous bases (A, T, G, C) project inward from this backbone and form the base pairs that constitute the genetic information. The phosphodiester bonds connecting the sugar-phosphate backbone give DNA its directional nature, with one end having a 5' phosphate and the other having a 3' hydroxyl group.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alternating sugars and nitrogenous bases: Incorrect because nitrogenous bases are not part of the backbone but rather project inward to form base pairs between the two strands of DNA.

 

Option B. Nitrogenous bases alone: Incorrect because bases are attached to the sugar components of the backbone via N-glycosidic bonds but do not themselves form the backbone structure.

 

Option C. Phosphate groups alone: Incorrect because phosphate groups alternate with deoxyribose sugar molecules to form the backbone; phosphates alone would not create the required structure.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The DNA backbone consists of alternating deoxyribose sugar and phosphate groups connected by 3',5'-phosphodiester bonds, which forms the structural framework of the double helix while the nitrogenous bases attached to the sugars encode the genetic information.

questions.text: Which is not a feature of 3rd nerve palsy? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Abduction limitation

 

This is not a feature of third nerve palsy. Abduction of the eye is controlled by the lateral rectus muscle, which is innervated by the sixth cranial nerve. Limitation in abduction is indicative of sixth nerve palsy, not third nerve palsy. In third nerve palsy, there would be a limitation of adduction (movement of the eye towards the nose) instead.

 

Other Options:

 

Third nerve palsy (oculomotor nerve palsy) presents with several characteristic features due to the loss of function of the muscles it innervates:

 

Option A. Pupil dilatation: The third cranial nerve carries parasympathetic fibers responsible for pupil constriction. Damage to this nerve results in unopposed sympathetic stimulation, leading to pupil dilatation (mydriasis).

 

Option B. Ptosis: The levator palpebrae superioris muscle, responsible for elevating the eyelid, is innervated by the third cranial nerve. Damage to this nerve causes ptosis (drooping of the eyelid).

 

Option C. Down and out eye: The unopposed action of the lateral rectus (innervated by the sixth cranial nerve) and the superior oblique (innervated by the fourth cranial nerve) results in the characteristic "down and out" position of the affected eye.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Third nerve palsy presents with pupil dilatation, ptosis, and a down and out eye. Abduction limitation is not a feature of third nerve palsy; it is seen in sixth nerve palsy.

questions.text: What is the inheritance pattern? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mitochondrial

 

The pedigree chart shown in Image 2 demonstrates a clear pattern of mitochondrial inheritance. Key characteristics of this inheritance pattern are:

 

  1. Maternal transmission: The disease is passed down exclusively from affected mothers to all their children (both sons and daughters).
  2. No paternal transmission: Affected fathers do not pass the condition to any of their offspring.
  3. All offspring of an affected mother are affected: This is because all mitochondria in a zygote come from the egg cell.

 

In the pedigree, we can see that in each generation, affected mothers (filled circles) transmit the condition to all their children, while affected fathers (filled squares) do not pass it on to any of their children.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autosomal Dominant: Incorrect. This pattern would show affected individuals in every generation, but both males and females would be able to transmit the condition to their offspring.

 

Option B. Autosomal Recessive: Incorrect. This pattern typically shows skip generations and requires both parents to be carriers or affected for the offspring to be affected.

 

Option C. X linked recessive: Incorrect. This pattern would show predominantly affected males, with females as carriers, and no male-to-male transmission.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mitochondrial inheritance is characterized by maternal transmission of a trait to all offspring, with no paternal transmission, due to the exclusive inheritance of mitochondria from the mother's egg cell

questions.text: In a patient in the ICU, an infection in the central venous catheter is noted. Staining showed a gram-positive oval-shaped organism that reproduces by budding. Identify the organism. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Candida

 

Candida is a genus of yeast and is the most common cause of fungal infections in humans. It is characterized by its oval shape and its mode of reproduction through budding, a form of asexual reproduction. In a healthcare setting, particularly in the ICU, Candida infections are commonly associated with the use of central venous catheters. The yeast can colonize and infect these catheters, leading to systemic infections. The identification of a gram-positive, oval-shaped organism that reproduces by budding points directly to Candida.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. E. coli: Escherichia coli is a gram-negative rod-shaped bacterium and does not reproduce by budding. It is typically associated with gastrointestinal infections, urinary tract infections, and other bacterial infections, but not with the description provided in this scenario.

 

Option C. Staph aureus: Staphylococcus aureus is a gram-positive coccus in clusters and does not reproduce by budding. It is a common cause of various infections, including skin infections and catheter-associated infections, but its morphology and reproduction do not match the description of a budding organism.

 

Option D. Staph epidermidis: Staphylococcus epidermidis is also a gram-positive cocci and part of the normal skin flora. It is a common contaminant in blood cultures and can cause infections associated with indwelling medical devices, but it does not reproduce by budding and does not have an oval shape.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Candida is an oval-shaped yeast that reproduces by budding and is a common cause of catheter-associated infections in ICU patients.

questions.text: Alder-Reilly bodies are found in: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Mucopolysaccharidosis.

 

Explanation: 

 

Alder-Reilly bodies are azurophilic, metachromatic granules found in leukocytes (neutrophils, eosinophils, basophils, monocytes, and lymphocytes) in patients with mucopolysaccharidosis. These abnormal inclusions represent accumulations of mucopolysaccharides (glycosaminoglycans) within the cytoplasm of these cells. Mucopolysaccharidoses are a group of inherited lysosomal storage disorders characterized by defective degradation of glycosaminoglycans due to enzyme deficiencies, leading to their accumulation in various tissues including blood cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Large platelets - This is incorrect. Large platelets are associated with several conditions including Bernard-Soulier syndrome, May-Hegglin anomaly, and immune thrombocytopenic purpura, but these do not feature Alder-Reilly bodies.

 

Option C. Alport's syndrome - This is incorrect. Alport's syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by progressive kidney disease, hearing loss, and eye abnormalities. It's caused by mutations in genes coding for type IV collagen and does not involve the formation of Alder-Reilly bodies.

 

Option D. Chediak-Higashi syndrome - This is incorrect. While Chediak-Higashi syndrome does involve abnormal granules in leukocytes, these are giant lysosomal granules rather than Alder-Reilly bodies. Chediak-Higashi syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by partial albinism, recurrent infections, and giant granules in leukocytes.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Alder-Reilly bodies are distinctive azurophilic granular inclusions found in leukocytes of patients with mucopolysaccharidosis, representing accumulated glycosaminoglycans due to defective lysosomal enzyme function.

questions.text: What is the photostress test used to differentiate between?  (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Macula and optic nerve disease

 

  • Photo stress test helps differentiate between diseases involving the macula and optic nerve.
  • This test is particularly useful in early macular diseases like central serous retinopathy.
  • One eye is covered and the patient is asked to read the smallest line on a near chart.
  • A bright light is shone into the eye for 15 seconds, and the patient is asked to read the line again.
  • The time taken to recover is noted, and the test is repeated with the other eye.
  • In normal people and patients with optic nerve disease, recovery time is not affected.
  • In patients with macular disease, recovery time is prolonged, usually more than one-third of the normal recovery time.
  • Photoreceptor damage and delayed visual pigment regeneration process contribute to prolonged recovery time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cataract and glaucoma: The photostress test is not designed to differentiate between cataract and glaucoma. Cataract affects the lens, while glaucoma primarily affects the optic nerve and intraocular pressure.

 

Option C. Lens and cornea: The photostress test does not help in differentiating between lens and corneal pathologies. Issues with the lens (e.g., cataracts) and cornea are typically diagnosed with slit-lamp examination and other tests.

 

Option D. Retina and vitreal pathologies: The photostress test is not specifically used to differentiate between retinal and vitreal pathologies. Other diagnostic methods, such as ophthalmoscopy, fundus photography, and optical coherence tomography (OCT), are more appropriate for these conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The photostress test is a simple and effective diagnostic tool used to differentiate between macular diseases and optic nerve diseases, based on the recovery time of vision following bright light exposure.

questions.text: Which nutrient deficiency is cause of night blindness? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin A

 

Night blindness, or nyctalopia, is a common symptom of vitamin A deficiency. Vitamin A is essential for the production of rhodopsin, a pigment found in the retina that is necessary for vision in low-light conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin C: Vitamin C deficiency does not typically cause night blindness. Vitamin C is important for overall health, but it is not directly involved in the visual process.

 

Option C. Vitamin B: Vitamin B deficiencies, such as vitamin B1 (thiamine) deficiency, can lead to various neurological symptoms but are not known to cause night blindness.

 

Option D. Vitamin D: Vitamin D deficiency primarily affects bone health and calcium metabolism. It is not associated with night blindness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Night blindness is commonly associated with vitamin A deficiency.

questions.text: According to NCEP-ATP III guidelines, which of the options below is not considered a criterion for metabolic syndrome? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) High LDL

 

High LDL: This is not a criterion for metabolic syndrome according to the NCEP-ATP III guidelines. While high LDL cholesterol is a significant risk factor for cardiovascular disease, it is not part of the metabolic syndrome criteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypertriglyceridemia: Elevated triglyceride levels are a criterion for metabolic syndrome and indicate dyslipidemia.

 

Option C. Central Obesity: Defined by waist circumference, this is a key criterion for metabolic syndrome and indicates visceral fat accumulation.

 

Option D. Hypertension: Elevated blood pressure is included in the criteria for metabolic syndrome, reflecting its association with increased cardiovascular risk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

According to NCEP-ATP III guidelines, criterion for metabolic syndromes are:

choices.text: First becomes more positive, then negative

questions.text: A patient was brought to the hospital after a road traffic accident. He had severe muscle injury and his serum K+ level was found to be 5.5 mEq/L. What change will happen to the resting membrane potential in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Becomes more positive

 

Explanation

 

In the given clinical scenario, the patient has hyperkalemia. Hyperkalemia can cause a shift in the resting membrane potential towards a more positive value, increased cell excitability, and impairments in membrane potential changes.

 

Hyperkalemia can affect the resting membrane potential of cells, including neurons and muscle cells, in the following ways:

 

  1. Increased Resting Membrane Potential: Normally, the resting membrane potential is around -70 millivolts (mV) in neurons. However, in hyperkalemia, the elevated extracellular potassium concentration can lead to an increased positive charge outside the cell. This positive charge tends to depolarize the cell membrane, shifting the resting membrane potential towards a more positive value.
  2. Altered Excitability: The increased resting membrane potential caused by hyperkalemia can make the cell more excitable. It reduces the threshold required for an action potential to be initiated, making the cell more likely to depolarize and generate an action potential even in response to weaker stimuli.
  3. Impaired Membrane Potential Changes: Hyperkalemia can interfere with the ability of the cell membrane to depolarize and repolarize properly during an action potential. It reduces the electrochemical gradient for sodium (Na+) entry during depolarization and decreases the driving force for potassium (K+) exit during repolarization. This can result in slower and less efficient propagation of action potentials.
  4.  Disrupted Ionic Balance: Elevated potassium levels can disrupt the balance of other ions, such as sodium and calcium, which are essential for normal cell function. The altered ionic balance can interfere with the proper functioning of ion channels and other membrane proteins involved in generating and regulating action potentials.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. No change: Incorrect. Changes in extracellular potassium concentrations directly impact the resting membrane potential.

 

Option B. Becomes more negative: Incorrect. An increase in extracellular potassium concentration results in depolarization (more positive resting membrane potential), not hyperpolarization.

 

Option D. First becomes more positive, then negative: Incorrect. While complex fluctuations can occur under dynamic conditions, primarily, hyperkalemia causes a persistent depolarization (more positive shift) without an initial opposite change.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In hyperkalemia, as seen in patients with severe muscle injury, the resting membrane potential becomes more positive due to decreased potassium efflux, leading to increased excitability of nerve and muscle cells. This can affect the normal function of these cells, potentially leading to complications such as muscle weakness or cardiac arrhythmias.

questions.text: Which is the most common cause of night blindness in pediatric age? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vitamin A deficiency

 

Explanation:

 

Night blindness, also known as nyctalopia, is the inability to see well in low light or darkness. The most common cause of night blindness in the pediatric age group is vitamin A deficiency. Vitamin A is essential for the production of rhodopsin, a pigment in the retina that is crucial for vision in low-light conditions.

 

Key Points:

  • Vitamin A deficiency: Leads to inadequate production of rhodopsin, resulting in night blindness.
  • Common causes of vitamin A deficiency: Poor dietary intake, malabsorption disorders, or increased requirements during periods of rapid growth.

 

Symptoms of Vitamin A Deficiency:

  • Night blindness
  • Xerophthalmia (dryness of the conjunctiva and cornea)
  • Bitot's spots (foamy patches on the conjunctiva)
  • Keratomalacia (softening of the cornea)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin C deficiency: Causes scurvy, characterized by bleeding gums and perifollicular hemorrhages, but not night blindness.

 

Option B. Congenital glaucoma: A rare condition that can affect vision but does not specifically cause night blindness.

 

Option D. Vitamin E deficiency: Can cause neurological problems and hemolytic anemia but is not typically associated with night blindness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin A deficiency is the most common cause of night blindness in the pediatric age group, emphasizing the importance of adequate intake of vitamin A for maintaining healthy vision, especially in low-light conditions.

questions.text: Function of IL-8 is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Chemotaxis

 

Interleukin-8 (IL-8) is a cytokine that primarily functions as a chemokine. It plays a crucial role in the immune response by attracting and activating neutrophils to sites of infection or inflammation through chemotaxis. This movement of neutrophils to the affected area helps in fighting infections effectively, as they are key cells in the innate immune response.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fever: Fever is primarily induced by cytokines such as IL-1, IL-6, and TNF-alpha, not IL-8. These cytokines act on the hypothalamus to increase body temperature, which is a part of the systemic inflammatory response.

 

Option C. Lymphocyte proliferation: Lymphocyte proliferation is mainly associated with cytokines such as IL-2, which stimulates the growth of T cells. IL-8 does not play a direct role in lymphocyte proliferation.

 

Option D. TH1 activation: TH1 activation is driven by cytokines like IL-12 and IFN-gamma, which promote the differentiation of T-helper cells into the TH1 subtype. IL-8 is not involved in this process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary function of IL-8 is to induce chemotaxis, particularly attracting neutrophils to sites of infection or inflammation.

questions.text: A patient was started on haloperidol for the treatment of schizophrenia. He develops torticollis, muscle spasm, and trismus. What is the next best step in the management? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Give benzhexol

 

The patient is experiencing acute dystonia, a common and early side effect of antipsychotic medications such as haloperidol.

 

Acute dystonia is characterized by involuntary muscle contractions, which can manifest as torticollis (neck muscle spasms), muscle spasms, and trismus (jaw muscle spasms).

 

The drug of choice for treating acute dystonia is an anticholinergic medication such as benzhexol (trihexyphenidyl) or benztropine or promethazine. These medications help relieve the muscle spasms quickly and are often administered intramuscularly in acute situations.

 

 Other Options:

 

Option A. Decrease the dose of haloperidol: While this might be considered after the acute episode is managed, it does not address the immediate need to relieve the dystonic symptoms.

 

Option B. Shift from haloperidol to clozapine: Clozapine is generally reserved for treatment-resistant schizophrenia (TRS) and is not the immediate treatment for acute dystonia.

 

Option C. Shift from haloperidol to fluphenazine: Fluphenazine, another typical antipsychotic, can also cause acute dystonia, making this option less effective for immediate relief.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Acute dystonia, an early side effect of antipsychotic treatment, is managed by administering an intramuscular anticholinergic medication such as benzhexol (trihexyphenidyl) or benztropine to quickly relieve muscle spasms.

questions.text: A child with acute lymphoblastic leukemia undergoes prophylactic irradiation prior to autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplantation. Which of the following will be the least affected? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Neurons

 

Explanation:

 

Neurons (Central nervous system) are the least affected by irradiation among the options given, due to their highly differentiated and non-dividing nature.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A. Spermatogonia: These are germ cells that continually divide and are highly sensitive to radiation, which can lead to infertility.

 

Option. B. Intestinal epithelial cells: These cells have a high turnover rate, making them very sensitive to radiation, which can result in gastrointestinal toxicity.

 

Option. D. Bone marrow/erythroid precursor cells: These cells are among the most sensitive to radiation due to their role in rapidly producing new blood cells, leading to potential marrow suppression.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Gradual prolongation of PR interval followed by a non-conducted P wave
Prolonged PR interval, and each P wave is followed by a QRS complex
Normal PR interval followed by a non-conducted P wave

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding first-degree AV block? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Prolonged PR interval, and each P wave is followed by a QRS complex

 

Explanation:

 

First-degree AV block is characterized by prolongation of the PR interval (>0.2 seconds or >200 milliseconds) with each P wave being followed by a QRS complex. This represents a delay in conduction through the AV node, but every atrial impulse still successfully conducts to the ventricles. On ECG, this appears as more than five small boxes between the P wave and QRS complex.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gradual prolongation of PR interval followed by a non-conducted P wave: Incorrect

 

  • Describes Mobitz
  • type I (Wenckebach) second-degree AV block, where PR lengthens progressively until a P wave fails to conduct

 

Option C. Presence of atrioventricular dissociation: Incorrect

 

  • Seen in third-degree (complete) heart block, where the atria and ventricles beat independently
  • P waves and QRS complexes have no relation to each other

 

Option D. Normal PR interval followed by a non-conducted P wave: Incorrect

 

  • Describes Mobitz type II second-degree AV block, where PR remains constant but occasional P waves fail to conduct

 

Educational Objective:

 

First-degree AV block is characterized by a prolonged PR interval (>0.2 seconds) with 1:1 conduction, where each P wave is followed by a QRS complex.

choices.text: Right gastric and right gastroepiploic artery
Right gastric and left gastric artery
Right gastroepiploic and short gastric vessels
Right gastric and short gastric vessels

questions.text: Ligation of the common hepatic artery would most likely compromise the blood supply to which of the following arteries? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Right gastric and right gastroepiploic artery

 

Ligation of the common hepatic artery will cause impairment in the blood supply through its branches i.e., right gastric artery and right gastroepiploic artery.

 

 

  • The common hepatic artery typically divides into the hepatic proper artery and the gastroduodenal artery.
  • The hepatic proper artery, in turn, gives rise to the right gastric artery (which supplies the lesser curvature of the stomach) and continues as the left and right hepatic arteries for the liver.
  • The gastroduodenal artery gives off the right gastroepiploic artery, which supplies the greater curvature of the stomach.
  • Thus, if the common hepatic artery is ligated, blood supply to both the right gastric and right gastroepiploic arteries would be impaired.

 

Branches of hepatic artery (Mnemonic Girls R So Cute)

 

  • Gastroduodenal artery > divides into right gastroepiploic and superior pancreaticoduodenal arteries.
  • Right gastric artery
  • Supra duodenal artery (inconstant)
  • Cystic artery

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right gastric and left gastric artery: While the right gastric artery does arise from the hepatic proper artery (a branch of the common hepatic artery), the left gastric artery arises directly from the celiac trunk. Ligation of the common hepatic artery would not affect the left gastric artery's blood supply.

 

Option C. Right gastroepiploic and short gastric vessels: The right gastroepiploic artery arises from the gastroduodenal artery (a branch of the common hepatic artery). The short gastric arteries, however, typically arise from the splenic artery, another direct branch of the celiac trunk. Therefore, ligation of the common hepatic artery would not affect the blood supply of the short gastric vessels.

 

Option D. Right gastric and short gastric vessels: As mentioned earlier, the right gastric artery arises from the hepatic proper artery. The short gastric arteries arise from the splenic artery. Ligation of the common hepatic artery would only affect the right gastric artery's blood supply, not the short gastric vessels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ligation of the common hepatic artery affects the blood supply to both the right gastric and right gastroepiploic arteries due to their derivation from the hepatic proper and gastroduodenal arteries respectively.

questions.text: FAST in the ATLS scheme is used for the evaluation of fluid in all of the following regions except: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C (Pleura)

 

Explanation: 

 

The FAST examination protocol aims to identify intraperitoneal bleeding in trauma patients. A typical FAST examination involves searching for blood or fluid in the pericardium and peritoneum. The peritoneal search focuses on the area between the liver and right kidney and posterior pelvis (between the rectum and bladder in men and between the rectum and uterus in women) as these are the most dependent portions of the abdominopelvic cavity when the patient is supine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pelvis - INCORRECT. The posterior pelvis is specifically mentioned as one of the areas assessed in the FAST examination, as it's one of the most dependent portions of the abdominopelvic cavity when the patient is supine.

 

Option B. Pericardium - INCORRECT. The FAST examination explicitly includes searching for blood or fluid in the pericardium.

 

Option D. Perisplenic - INCORRECT. The perisplenic region would be included in the peritoneal evaluation, which is part of the FAST examination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The FAST (Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma) examination primarily evaluates for free fluid in the pericardium and key dependent areas of the peritoneum, not in the pleural spaces.

questions.text: A study was undertaken to evaluate the effect of Dietary modification on Serum cholesterol. A group of 100 people were chosen. Their mean cholesterol levels were measured before and after dietary modification. Which statistical test should be applied to test significance? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Paired students t-test

 

The paired students t-test is used when comparing the means of two related groups, specifically when data is collected from the same individuals before and after an intervention. In this question, the study measures serum cholesterol levels before and after dietary modification in the same group of people, making the data paired. This test is ideal for assessing whether the mean difference between the paired observations (pre- and post-intervention) is statistically significant.

 

Since the data is quantitative and normally distributed, a parametric test such as the paired t-test is appropriate. The paired t-test accounts for the fact that each participant has two related measurements (before and after), which reduces variability compared to independent measurements.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Odds Ratio:  This option is incorrect because the odds ratio is used to measure the association between two categorical variables, not for comparing means of quantitative data.

 

Option B. Chi-square test:  This test is used to compare categorical data and is not suitable for comparing means of quantitative measurements.

 

Option D. McNemar test:  This test is used to analyze paired categorical data, specifically for before-and-after studies with binary outcomes, not for comparing continuous variables like cholesterol levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The paired students t-test is the appropriate statistical test for comparing means of paired quantitative data collected from the same group before and after an intervention.

questions.text: Which gene is affected in Reiter's syndrome?  (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HLA-B27

 

Explanation:

 

Reiter's syndrome, also known as reactive arthritis, is strongly associated with the HLA-B27 gene. The presence of the HLA-B27 gene is a risk factor for developing Reiter's syndrome.

 

Reiter's syndrome is a type of spondyloarthritis, a group of inflammatory diseases that primarily affect the spine and joints. It is characterized by a triad of symptoms: arthritis (joint inflammation, typically affecting the knees, ankles, and feet), conjunctivitis (inflammation of the eye), and urethritis (inflammation of the urethra).

 

The HLA-B27 gene is a component of the human leukocyte antigen (HLA) system, which plays a crucial role in the immune system's recognition of foreign substances. The association between HLA-B27 and Reiter's syndrome suggests that the gene may contribute to the development of the condition, possibly by influencing the immune response.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HLA-DR3: This gene is associated with autoimmune diseases such as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), Hashimoto's thyroiditis, and Graves' disease.

 

Option B. HLA-DR4: This gene is strongly linked to rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Option D. HLA-DQ8: This gene, along with HLA-DQ2, is associated with celiac disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The HLA-B27 gene is the primary genetic factor associated with the development of Reiter's syndrome, a type of spondyloarthritis characterized by a triad of arthritis, conjunctivitis, and urethritis.
